journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Consumer total ownership cost model of plug-in hybrid vehicle in China

article-meta.aff: Tongji University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *Room B204, School of Automotive Studies, Tongji University, 4800 Caoan Road, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China. email: wangning7712@gmail.com

abstract.p: This paper used Advisor to define structures and power trains of parallel plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs), made two PHEV models that have different battery electric ranges of 20 km and 60 km, established consumer total ownership cost models based on purchase, and used cost and compared with a conventional vehicle (CV) and conventional hybrid vehicles. Then three scenarios were defined – government subsidy (US$2571 for PHEV20 and US$7143 for PHEV60 according to Chinese policy, where in this paper 1 US$ = 7.00 RMB), high oil price (10 per cent annual growth rate), and government subsidy and high oil price – and PHEV market competitiveness was analysed during a 15 year nominal lifecycle. The results show that in the government subsidy scenario a PHEV’s total ownership cost will be lower than that of a CV after 5 years without a battery replacement and 7 years with a battery replacement; in the high oil price scenario it separately needs 6 years and 8 years to show an advantage; in the government subsidy and high oil price, which is the most optimistic scenario, it only respectively needs 4 years and 5 years. It is shown that the government subsidy has a much more obvious effect during the first industrialization stage, but the high oil price has a long time function during the nominal lifecycle and the battery replacement cost is not a sensible factor to include in the PHEV’s total ownership cost.

kwd-group.kwd: government subsidy and high oil price scenario

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: In the 21st century, humans are facing unprecedented huge challenges based on energy and the environment. Ma et al. [1] studied the supply and demand driving factors of Chinese renewable and fossil energy, and pointed out how China’s policies, economy, and population will affect the global world in the future. Thus China’s energy policies will simultaneously face change and challenges, with clean energy being an urgent important trend. Moriaty and Honnery [2] pointed out that ‘green vehicles’ can solve two problems: air pollution and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Schäfer et al. [3] indicated that it is imperative to use battery electric vehicles (BEVs) and hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) in order to decrease energy consumption and GHG emissions. Van Mierlo and Maggetto [4], Werber et al. [5], Fischer et al. [6], and Cosmi et al. [7] claimed that BEV and petrol–electric hybrid vehicles are current transportation solutions.

The electric vehicle (EV) industrial studies of domestic and international origin mainly focus on technique stability, reliability, technology cost tendency, policy motivation mechanisms, and the strategy of industrial development. Yigang [8] pointed out that there were some problems to be solved for EV industrialization such as decreasing the cost, EV synthetic function improvement, infrastructure construction, and government policy support. Werber et al. [5] compared the lifecycle cost of a BEV and an automobile with the same power under different cruising ranges and petrol prices; the results showed that only in the condition of short range and high petrol price was the BEV lifecycle cost competitive. Additionally, a BEV with a range of 150 km can meet most consumers’ needs on technique, cost, performance, and efficiency. Silva et al. [9] studied the energy consumption, emission, and cost of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs). Hoyer [10] analysed and compared the impact of a BEV and an HEV on energy security, environment, and sustainable development, and the role of preventing climate change. Roche et al. [11] carried out a public attitude and demand quantitative investigation on the new energy vehicles, and concluded that private users were most concerned about the character of the products in the following order: cost of purchase and use, charging and refuelling time and range, accessibility of charging and refuelling, possibility of using different kinds of energy, and decreasing GHG emissions. Studies on EV policies mainly focused on the economic performance of social impact and technology advance, and the corresponding subsidies, tax concessions, and fee reduction.

According to the above references, consumers’ purchase cost and the costs of use are the key factors to the PHEV’s development and popularization, in addition to policies that also make concessions to the need to analyse the cost to consumers. However, there is still a lack of studies on quantitative research of consumers’ costs. This paper uses Advisor software to simulate the key component structures, size, and economy based on PHEV’s technique features, makes a consumer ownership cost model, and analyses the market competitiveness under three scenarios: government subsidy, high oil price, and government subsidy and high oil price.

sec.title: 2 PHEV Drive Mode
sec.p: A PHEV has two power sources: electricity and petrol. Through the use of a rational power control strategy, it can give higher performance, better economy, lower emission and cost [12]. The power control strategy determines two power sources using the time and working mode and controls the path of power to reach the wheel so as to switch to different drive modes [13] (Fig. 1): charging–depleting mode (CD), charging–sustaining mode (CS), and normal charging mode. In the CD mode, the PHEV matches the ‘electricity consumption–battery electric drive’ and ‘electricity consumption–hybrid drive’ modes according to power requirements. In the first scenario, the inner combustion engine (ICE) is shut off, the battery being the only power source. The state of charge (SOC) drops continuously and normally reaches part of the vehicle dynamic indicators. This mode is especially suited for starting, low-speed and low-load applications. In the second scenario, the ICE and electric motor work together. The battery provides the main part of the vehicle power demand and the ICE is used to supplement the shortage of power until the SOC reaches a minimum allowable value. This mode is suitable for high speed, especially when power performance to required to meet particular applications. When the SOC reaches the default minimum allowable value, the vehicle will be automatically turned to the CS mode. In this mode, the PHEV works like an HEV and basically retains the same battery SOC.

sec.title: 3 Basic Assumptions
sec.p: The paper defines the vehicle models PHEV20km, PHEV60km, HEV, and CV at the same power level in order to compare vehicle dynamic performance, efficiency, cost, and so on. From references [14] and [15] it can be seen that a parallel structure is the most efficient mode, so the PHEV model based on a parallel hybrid system is used here, with the layout shown in Fig. 2.

sec.title: 3.1 Vehicle parameters and performances
sec.p: Parameters of the HEV and PHEV determine the vehicle dynamics, fuel economy, emission, and manufacturing cost. Based on main popular compact cars in the Chinese market, this paper assumes that the aerodynamic coefficient of drag is 0.3, windward area is 2.1 m2, rolling resistance coefficient is 0.008, curb weight is 999 kg, load weight is 136 kg, wheel rolling radius is 0.275 m, and average electrical equipment load is 500 W. Performance targets are: 0–100 km/h acceleration time is 13 s, top speed is 150 km/h, largest degree of climbing in 50 km/h is 7.2 per cent, battery electric range of CV and HEV is 0 km, and of PHEV is 20 km and 60 km. The initial SOC of the HEV and PHEV (PHEV under a PCT test) separately is 65 per cent and 35 per cent.

sec.title: 3.2 Electricity power consumption
sec.p: According to the test result of a PHEV such as Chevrolet Volt by EPA, the PHEV electricity power consumption is assumed to be 225 W h/km. Considering SOC demands for battery efficiency and lifetime protection, only 75 per cent of electric power can be effectively used.

To analyse the traffic habit impact that the charging habits of different user groups have on fuel economy, assume that the travel probabilities of a fully charged and a CS mode are 50 per cent for both.

sec.title: 3.3 Components manufacturing cost
sec.p: In this paper, the PHEV, HEV, and CV are based on a similar platform and all are in mass production. In the next 5 years, each production will reach 100 000 units. As only the PHEV has a cost advantage and thus can successfully hit the automobile market, this means it should be in mass production with components at low cost.

sec.title: 4.1 Powertrain components selection
sec.p: The selection of powertrain type and performance parameters is a key step in the modelling process, which is important to vehicle performance. The main component technique parameters to be confirmed include: ICE type (gasoline, diesel), electric motor type (d.c., a.c., etc.) and battery type (lead–acid, Ni–Cd, Ni–MH, Li–ion). There are two steps to define: the first is using the Advisor software database to choose basic component types and parameters; and the second is further to optimize and determine the size and parameters according to the basic component feature.

Firstly, based on the characteristics of Chinese vehicle fuel use and compact car engine features, the Saturn 1.9 L gasoline ICE in the Advisor database is selected to power the CV. As in the HEV and PHEV the electric motor and engine work together, the Prius2004 1.5 L gasoline ICE is selected as the power engine. The MC_PM 49 is defined as the electric motor, familiar for its use in the Honda EV PLUS. The parameters of the ICE and electric motor are listed in Table 1 and rev–torque features are shown in Figs 3, 4, and 5.

caption.p: Parameters of a selected ICE/electric motor

sec.p: The Ni–MN battery is the most appropriate for use in mass production at this stage as it has been successfully used in the Toyota Prius, while the Li–ion battery has not been used in mass production in the automobile industry; therefore the Ni–MN battery has been selected as the power battery for the PHEV. The detailed parameters are listed in Table 2.

sec.title: 4.2 Powertrain components parameter optimization
sec.p: The battery electric range target design is the key factor to determine the size and quantity of the battery. The electric power consumption can be counted by the product of the battery electric range and electricity consumption per kilometre. In order to meet the range target of 20 km and 60 km, the corresponding efficient electricity power of the battery is 4.5 kW h and 13.5 kW h and the needed battery power should be 6 kW h and 18 kW h respectively. According to features of the ESS_NIMH45_OVONIC battery listed in Table 2, it can be calculated that PHEV20km and PHEV60km respectively need 10 and 30 modules to make up a battery pack. As for the conventional HEV, 40 modules are needed when referring to Toyota Prius.

Electric motor selection should consider three conditions: first is matching with the battery power; second is the meeting of designed performance parameters under the assignment condition operating mode; and third is the consideration of an appropriately increased safety margin with motor efficiency and electrical equipment. Based on the determination of the electric motor, the required minimum engine size can be described to meet the specified acceleration and climbing conditions. The powertrain component parameters based on calculation by Advisor software of an automatically optimized system are listed in Table 3.

sec.title: 4.3 Economy analysis by Advisor
sec.p: This paper used the MATLAB/Simulink tool to model the primary simulation module, which was inserted into Advisor to make the PHEV simulation model join on to the parallel default system (Fig. 6).

The operating condition of the cycle determines the PHEV energy consumption. The paper used standard J1711, Recommended practice for measuring the exhaust emissions and fuel economy of hybrid-electric vehicles, including plug-in hybrid-electric vehicles, by SAE for reference and utilized Urban dynamometer driving schedule and Highway fuel economy cycle by EPA as the standard condition to study the economy of the CD and CS mode. The UF (utility factor) was used to determine the proportion and to analyse effectively the economy of different drive modes in Fig 7.

The fuel economy test is appropriate for the full-driving mode of the CV and HEV and the CS mode tested by the PCT of the PHEV, which is shown in Table 4. The PHEV battery–electric mode energy consumption tested by the FCT is shown in Table 5. Based on these tests, the UF was introduced to analyse the PHEV fuel economy, which is shown in Table 6. According to the J1711 standard, in order to calculate the energy economy of all driving ranges, the equivalent E-gasoline coefficient is used to convert all electricity and petrol consumption results to a gasoline economy expression. Finally, the PHEV fuel economy is a mean value of the PCT, FCT, and UF, which is shown in Table 7.

caption.p: Fuel economy considering the UF weight

sec.title: 5 PHEV Consumer Ownership Cost Model
sec.p: Consumer total ownership cost refers to the economics cost accumulation generated by vehicle ownership and use, including the purchase cost and the cost of use in this study.

sec.title: 5.1 Purchase cost
sec.p: The purchase cost is made up of direct costs including vehicle manufacturing and assembly cost, indirect costs, and tax preference. The PHEV, HEV, and CV share similar chassis and body parts, which hold 70–80 per cent of total cost [16]. For the PHEV, there is only an estimate of the cost of the unique engine, electric motor, battery, and charging system.

sec.title: 5.1.1 Vehicle manufacturing and assembly cost
sec.p: The vehicle manufacturing and assembly cost mainly includes the basic parts' manufacturing cost, ICE cost, electric motor cost, battery cost, and charger cost.

The ICE cost is mainly determined by maximum power and is made up of two parts: first is the ICE body cost, which is related to the cylinder numbers and displacement mode; and second is the thermal management system cost, which is a positive correlation with engine power [17]. An inline four-cylinder engine is used for simulation in Advisor software and its cost can be regressed, based on the Simpson report [18]. The empirical equations are CL4ICE body cost(US$) = 12 × PICE max power + 424 and CManagement system (US$) = 0.236 × PICE max power, and the simulation results of the ICE cost are shown in Table 8.

The HEV and PHEV models both use a brushless permanent-magnet a.c. motor. The a.c. motor system includes a motor, controller, and thermal management device. Since the battery is a constant voltage device, the motor controller adjusts the current to change the motor’s torque. However, current–torque features vary with different motor designs, so controllers should be designed for specific motors. In this study, controller cost differences result from controller feature variations and so are ignored. Cost variation caused by motor controller difference is ignored in this paper. The motor thermal management system cost is relatively stable, but the d.c.–d.c. controller cost largely depends on the motor annual production. Based on a vehicle assumption production of 100 000 units per year, the cost can be obtained through the data regression of a common market price and a motor company interview. Based on the Duvall report [19], the empirical equations are Cmotor(US$) = 13.7 × Pmaxpower + 190, Ccontroller(US$) = 7.86 × Pmax power + 105.7, and Cthermal management (US$) = 1 × Pmax power + 71.4. For the CV, a traditional starter motor is needed and its price is approximately US$42.8 according to the same type used in the market. Simulation results of a motor system cost are shown in Table 9.

The cost of a battery depends on the energy storage size of the battery, based on Duvall’s report in 2004 [19]. The battery package cost mainly depends on the raw materials' cost, and once it is in mass production the manufacturing cost has the opportunity to decline. Through the outlook of California CEI Professor Kalhammer [20], there is a certain relationship between the battery module cost and the power/energy ratio, so the battery cost equation expression can be obtained based on the 100 000 production volume. For the HEV (power/energy ratio is 20), CB_HEV_m = 440 × Ecapacity; for PHEV20 and PHEV60 (power/energy ratio is 5.5), CB_PHEV20_m = 270 × Ecapacity and CB_PHEV60_m = 270 × Ecapacity. Based on a report of the Topology Research Institute, the cost of a battery pack is the product of the cost of the battery module and a multiplier, which depends on battery capacity [21]. The multipliers and simulation results of the battery cost are shown in Table 10. For the CV, a traditional lead–acid battery is needed and its price is approximately US$40.

The PHEV needs a charging device to convert a.c. to d.c. and store it in a battery. At the same time, it can control the charging speed and automatically cut off the power charging process when the battery is fully charged in order to protect the battery. At present, this device price is approximately US$430 [19].

The PHEV, HEV, and CV in this study share a similar body and structure and their manufacturing platforms and volume of productions are similar. Therefore they have the same cost of basic parts. Compared with the HEV and PHEV, the CV market price and manufacturing cost are much easier to obtain, as the basic parts' cost can be obtained from the difference value of the CV total cost and the cost of special parts corresponding to the HEV. The basic parts' cost of a compact vehicle (gross weight is 1320 kg) in mass production is about US$8571 [22]. Simulation results of the total cost are shown in Table 11.

Figure 8 shows that with the growth of the PHEV electric range, the battery costs increase sharply. The battery costs are accounted for separately as 17 per cent and 35 per cent for models PHEV20km and PHEV60km.

sec.title: 5.1.2 Indirect cost
sec.p: According to previous analyses, indirect cost includes the production management cost, operation management cost, sales cost, and profit. Indirect cost is difficult to calculate directly. This paper estimates for the major automotive industry manufacturers the proportional relationship between the cost of production and marketing and direct costs, and calculates the equivalent coefficient u to show the relationship between direct and indirect costs of carmakers. The statistics shows that the average u of global multinational carmakers is between 0.45 and 0.49, which was taken from the 2006 to 2008 annual report of carmakers. A value of u to be used was assumed to be 0.47. According to the formula Cindirect cost = Ctotal manufacturing cost × u, the indirect costs are as shown in Table 12.

sec.title: 5.1.3 Government tax
sec.p: In China, the consumer should pay purchase tax directly, which depends on the vehicle price and payment of the purchase but does not include value added tax (VAT). Therefore the vehicle purchase tax formula can be obtained as: assessable price for tax payment (excluding tax) = (all price + other payment) ÷ (1 + VAT rate 17%). The purchase tax payment is 10 per cent of this assessable price and the results are shown in Table 13.

sec.title: 5.2 Usage cost
sec.p: Usage cost includes petrol/electricity cost and maintenance cost. The nominal driving lifetime and travel pattern are very important for cost analysis. The driving plan (mileage per day, proportion of highway and city condition, charging frequency) determines the simulated vehicle driving range per year during its lifetime and the battery electric range proportion. Different energy usage costs are calculated based on a previous economy analysis.

sec.title: 5.2.1 Fuel cost
sec.p: According to Chinese regulations, a car nominal driving lifetime is 15 years or 600 000 km, depending on which comes first. Consumer travel habit includes usage frequency, usage time, and travel range, which is very important to the PHEV. For the PHEV, how long a time of the battery electric range depends on the travel habit and charging frequency. To investigate this 80 Shanghai car owners were chosen and their travel for 10 days in 2010 was logged by the Automotive Marketing and Management Institute, Tongji University, to determine the consumer travel habit. According to the record of their everyday driving ranges, the PHEV battery electric range was calculated and the results are shown in Table 14.

In Shanghai, 93 gasoline (the most common used) had a national government set price of 1.11 US$/L in April 2011, while residential electricity prices were 0.088 US$/kW h. Supposing that the PHEV charging efficiency is 85 per cent, the charging price is 0.103 US$/kW h. Gasoline and charging costs are calculated and shown in Table 15. Since the charging price is only a small part of the PHEV lifetime cost and the electricity charging price can fluctuate by 30 per cent, its influence to the lifetime cost is not over 3 per cent, so electricity price variations in different cities are not discussed further.

tr.td: Average electricity use per year (kW h)

sec.p: The PHEV and HEV maintenance cost is difficult to analyse because mass production has not started and there is a lack of operational data to count. This paper is therefore based on the CV ICE maintenance statistical cost, listing the key changes because of energy structure variation leading to maintenance differences, which is mainly the cost savings of ICE system simplification or the decrease in use. The maintenance cost of the PHEV and HEV was obtained from the Clean Energy Automobile Center, Tongji University, and the results are shown in Table 16.

sec.title: 5.3 Consumer ownership cost model
sec.p: For consumers, the ownership cost includes the purchase cost and usage cost. The purchase cost is a fixed cost, consisting of the vehicle manufacturing cost and coresponding tax. Usage cost, including the energy consumption cost and maintenance cost, changes with passing years. Therefore, the consumer ownership cost equation can be obtained as

Although the PHEV manufacturing cost is much higher than those of the CV and HEV, consumers can get some economic benefits from the usage phase, which has a lower energy consumption cost. This paper uses the equilibrium analysis method to compare the PHEV, CV, and HEV lifetime total cost. This method, which is shown in Fig. 9, calculates the mileage or used years when the decrease of energy consumption cost and maintainance cost just compensates for the increase in manufacturing cost, and this value can then be judged over the vehicle lifetime [22]. The model is shown by
Further discussion will be given based on this equal mileage or used years.

Considering that the lifetime of the PHEV60 Ni–MH battery is about 150 000 km and the PHEV20 Ni–MH battery is about 50 000 km [19], they should be replaced one time during the PHEV nominal lifetime. The replacement cost is equal to the battery manufacturing cost shown in Table 10. The battery replacement cost as part of the usage cost is divided equally into each year, and compared with results without battery replacement.

Based on the situation of 2011, where the gasoline price is 1.11 US$/L, although the PHEV has a lower energy cost and maintenance cost, its purchase cost is too high so that the equal point comes at the end of the PHEV lifetime. Thus the PHEV has no competitiveness without government subsidy, which is shown in Fig. 10.

caption.p: Ownership cost in original situation (a) without battery replacement and (b) with battery replacement

sec.p: However, the Chinese government has introduced some policies to improve new energy vehicle development, so three different scenarios are now defined. First is the high oil price scenario: it is noted that the gasoline price average annual growth is 9.94 per cent from the year 1998 to 2010, so it can be supposed that in the coming 15 years, the 93 gasoline price annual growth will be 10 per cent in China. Second is the government subsidies scenario: according to Chinese Notice of subsidies to individuals buying new energy vehicle demonstration, the PHEV can obtain one-time subsidies of 428.6 US$/kW h, based on the capacity of its power battery, but no more than US$7143 in total. Thus PHEV20km and PHEV60km can obtain US$2571 and US$7143 subsidies. The HEV, as an energy-saving vehicle with a displacement of less than 1.6 L, can only gain a subsidy of US$428.6. Third is the high oil price and government subsidy scenario: the gasoline price will increase as mentioned in the first scenario, while government subsidy can also be obtained as in the second scenario.
Based on the calculated results in Fig. 10 and the travel habit shown in Table 14, the consumer total ownership costs for the three scenarios can be obtained, as shown in Figs 11, 12, and 13.

caption.p: Ownership cost in high oil price scenario (a) without battery replacement and (b) with battery replacement
Ownership cost in subsidies scenario (a) without battery replacement and (b) with battery replacement
Ownership cost in high oil price and subsidies scenario (a) without battery replacement and (b) with battery replacement

sec.p: From Figs 11(a) and (b), it is found that about 7 or 8 years later the PHEV total ownership cost will be equal to that of the CV without battery replacement and 1 more year later with battery replacement. This means that by about the year 2020 the PHEV will be competitive in the high oil price scenario. Therefore fuel cost is a key factor in improving new energy vehicle industrialization and the high oil price development trend will accelerate the popularization progress.

The ownership cost in subsidies scenario is shown in Figs 12(a) and (b). Based on the government subsidies, the PHEV will show an advantage after 5 years without a battery replacement and two additional years with a battery replacement, which means about the year 2016 to 2018. Thus, the ownership cost advantage gained from the subsidy is more obvious in the early years, but during the nominal lifecycle it will be less than the advantage gained from a high oil price.

In the high oil price and government subsidies scenario, which is the most optimistic, the PHEV will get the greatest ownership cost advantage, which is shown in Figs 13(a) and (b). It is about 4 years later without a battery replacement and 5 years later with a battery replacement, which means that in the year 2015 the PHEV will be competitive.

sec.title: 6 Conclusions
sec.p: This paper studied the consumers’ purchase cost and usage cost and calculated the PHEV consumer ownership cost based on an Advisor economy simulation. Through a comparison of three different scenarios, the following conclusions were obtained.

list-item.p: Oil price is a sensible factor to the PHEV consumer ownership cost in the lifecycle time. Considering that the Chinese gasoline price annual growth may be more than 10 per cent, it is very good to accelerate the PHEV popularization.

Government subsidies will be more conducive than a high oil price to the promotion of the PHEV at the present time, and with more positive support of policy, such as parking concessions, unlimited purchasing and driving, consumers will be more likely to buy the PHEV. However, a high oil price has a longer time function to promote PHEV industrialization.

With the common influence of both a high oil price and government subsidies, the PHEV will have a very good chance of popularization and industrialization. Consumers will accept the purchasing cost and usage cost more easily.

Even though the battery may need to be replaced one time during the car lifetime, the PHEV ownership cost will not increase sharply – it is not a sensible factor for consumer purchasing behaviour. Thus, the PHEV is a good choice for the Chinese market in the coming decade. The Chinese government should maintain the subsidy and give more impetus to the PHEV promotion.

fn.p: This work was financially supported by Soft Science Foundation of Science and Technology Commission of Shanghai Municipality. The authors acknowledge the help of Clean Energy Automotive Center, Tongji University.
